The Computer Club at P.I. Middle School also meets monthly. Zack and Marta suggested that the club design a computer game that involves several animated characters. They ask Martaâ€™s uncle Carlos, a programmer for a video game company, about computer animation.

Carlos explains that the computer screen can be thought of as a grid made up of thousands of tiny points, called pixels. To animate a figure, we need to enter the coordinates of key points on the figure. The computer uses these points to draw the figure in different positions.

Sometimes the figures in a computer game need to change size. A change in the programming code can make a figure larger or smaller. We can code a rule for finding key points from the original figure. In this Investigation, we will explore answers to these questions.

Do the rules create scale drawings? That is, are the two figures similar?

The following problems will help us answer these questions.
